arch:property.oc:show_val: Uneven mud plaster surface located in the eastern half of the trench. Abuts wall 7212 on its northern side. In the center of the surface is a sunken pit, measuring 55 x 55 x 3-5cm in depth. This pit is also plastered therefore it was included within this locus. The floor is burnt with the heaviest concentration of burning in the sunken pit area (fire pit?). On the eastern side, the floor slopes up to meet an in situ door socket that has been sunk into the surface in the northeast corner of the locus. Though not directly abutting, this surface and surface 7213 can be considered associated or related based on color, texture, elevation, and mud plastering technique. Excavated using the Household Archaeology Protocol (HAP). A total of 45 liters were collected.

arch:note.arch:string: Contexts excavated in trenches were recorded using the "locus system." A locus is any discrete three-dimensional entity excavated in a trench. The key to the locus system is the recognition that a locus is any one thing. Differences in soil composition or texture are therefore as important as, for example, the difference between a pit and a wall. If two entities were distinct, they were considered separate loci and were therefore assigned separate locus numbers. It should also be noted that every context excavated in a trench was given a locus number and thus the trench itself is made up completely of excavated loci.

oc:metadata.dc:title: Kenan Tepe: Area F / Trench 7 / Locus 7219 (Locus)
